4.2.1. Criterios de Selección de Eventos para K3π

Para la selección de eventos, así como para la determinación del vértice de decaimiento del K+ se escribió el
programa Lifetime.cc que funciona empleando el framework del experimento. Dentro de este código se encuentra
una sección especifica para K3π. Para dicha selección se emplean los siguiente criterios.

Formación de un vértice: Los vértices deben formarse con la intersección de 3 trayectorias. El χ2 tanto
de la reconstrucción de trayectorias como de la formación del vértice debe ser menor a 20, y contar con un
tiempo asociado por los CHOD.

Coincidencia en tiempo: El tiempo asociado al vértice y el tiempo asociado por el ControlTrigger no deben
diferir en más de 3ns.

Vértice en el volumen fiducial: El vértice debe estar entre el GTK3 y los STRAWS, por lo tanto su
posición en Z debe corresponder a 105m < Z < 175m.

Vértice en la región del haz: El vértice debe haber sido creado en el haz, se considera a esta región en el
plano XY como (−50, 50)X(−25, 25)mm2.

Conservación de la carga: La carga del K+ corresponde a +e, la suma de la carga de las trayectorias
también debe corresponder a +e, y corresponder a la carga de dos π+ y un π−.

Veto a eventos con fotones: No hay fotones dentro de los productos de este decaimiento, por este motivo
no deben detectarse clusters neutrales en el LKr, ni actividad en los LAVs, IRC, ni SAC.

Conservación de la dirección del momento: El momento de los kaones se conserva, por lo tanto la
suma de momentos de los piones producidos debe corresponder a la del Kaón, tanto en magnitud como en
sentido. Por este motivo, la suma del momento de los piones no debe tener componentes transversales al
haz, únicamente longitudinales. Rechazar los eventos con momento transversal total del vértice distinto de
cero sería un corte drástico, por tal motivo se propuso que el valor de este momento transversal sea menor a
30MeV/C.

Conservación de la magnitud del momento: Análogo al punto anterior, la magnitud del vector resultante
de la suma del momento de los piones debe corresponder al del momento del Kaón, el cual nominalmente es
75GeV/c. Para no tener una condición tan restrictiva, se tomo como condición que la magnitud del momento
del vértice no difiriese con el del haz en más de 2GeV/c.

Conservación del cuadrimomento: El cuadrimomento del Kaón, Pk, corresponde a la suma de los cua-
drimomentos de los tres piones, Pπi . La norma cuadrada del cuadrimomento de una partícula corresponde a
su masa al cuadrado, por lo tanto, empleando la conservación del cuadrimomento se llega a la ecuación 37,
donde c es la velocidad de la luz.

(Mk+ c)2 = ||Pπ1

4.2.2. Criterios Comunes de Selección de Eventos para K2π y Kµ2

Al igual que para la selección de eventos para k3π, la selección de eventos se realiza mediante el programa
Lifetime.cc. En particular tanto K2π como Kµ2 cuentan exclusivamente con una trayectoria, correspondiente a las
partículas (el π+ para K2π, y el µ+ para Kµ2). Para sobrellevar esto, se buscan que las trayectorias cargadas formen
un vértice con el haz de kaones, los criterios de selección de vértices válidos se listan a continuación.

Formación de vértice: Debe identificarse una sola trayectoria, la cual debe contar con un χ2 < 20. Además,
esta debe formar un vértice con el haz y contenerse dentro del volumen fiducial, 105m < Z < 175m.

Conservación de la carga: La carga en el decaimiento es conservada, por tanto, la carga de la trayectoria
debe ser de +e, correspondiente a su vez a la carga del π+ o del µ+.

Restricción al momento de la trayectoria: La trayectoria debe tener un momento contenido entre los
5GeV/c a los 70GeV/c.

Posición del vértice en el haz: Si bien se pide que la trayectoria forme un vértice con el haz, pero este
vértice acarrea un error en su posición. Por este motivo, se pide que para una cierta posición en Z, la posición
en X del vértice no difiera con respecto a la posición del haz en X en más de 20mm. El mismo criterio es
empleado para la posición en Y del vértice. en las figuras 26 y 27, puede apreciarse la diferencia de posición,
tanto en X, como en Y, para K2π y Kµ2 respectivamente.

Señal y tiempo asociados al RICH: Tanto el pión como el muón cuentan con suficiente momento como
para generar luz Cherenkov en el RICH, por este motivo se requiere que la trayectoria obtenida tenga una
señal asociada al RICH. También se pide que el RICH pueda asociar un tiempo a la trayectoria, este será el
tiempo de la trayectoria.

Coincidencia en tiempo con señal en el CEDAR: Puesto que se busca que el vértice provenga del
decaimiento de un Kaón, se busca que haya señal en el CEDAR el cual es empleado como identificador de
Kaones. Para ello se requiere que mínimo 4 sectores de este se activen y que, además, el tiempo de esta señal
no difiera en mas de 0.4ns respecto al tiempo asociado a la trayectoria.

4.2.3. Criterios Específicos de Selección de Eventos para K2π

Los criterios específicos de selección de eventos para K2π son los siguientes:

Ausencia de señal asociada a muones: Se requiere que la trayectoria no tenga una señal asociada al
MUV3, esto con la finalidad de no mezclar eventos provenientes de modos de decaimiento con muones. La
validez de este criterio de selección tiene una restricción, y es que es necesario que la trayectoria esté dentro
de la aceptancia geométrica del MUV3.

Congruencia en tiempo con el Trigger: Se requiere que el tiempo de la trayectoria no difiera en mas de
3ns respecto al tiempo del ControlTrigger.

34



Detección de los fotones provenientes del decaimiento del π0: Puesto que el π0 tiene carga eléctrica
neutra y vive poco tiempo, su detección solo puede realizarse a través de sus productos de decaimiento, en
este caso un par de fotones. Para la detección de estos, se emplea el LKr, y se pide como condición que en este
se formen dos clusters provenientes del paso de ambos fotones por el detector. Para asumir que los fotones
provinieron del mismo pión, se requiere que el tiempo de ambos clusters no difieran en mas de 4ns con respecto
al tiempo de la trayectoria.

Veto a fotones: Puesto que fueron detectados dos fotones en el Lkr, se requiere que no haya en el evento la
detección de más de dos fotones, por este motivo se requiere que no haya señales asociadas a los LAVs, IRC
ni SAC.

Missing Mass correspondiente a la masa del π0: Partiendo de la conservación del cuadrimomento, y
conociendo el cuadrimomento del K+ y el π+, es posible determinar el cuadrimomento del π0. Haciendo uso
de la norma cuadrada de esta diferencia de momento se obtiene la masa del pión, la partícula que no se mide
directamente, de ahí que se denomine a esta masa, Missing Mass.

Pπ0 = PK+ − Pπ+ −→ (Mπ0c)2 = ||PK+ − Pπ+ ||2. (38)

En nuestro caso, se conoce el cuadrimomento del k+ a partir de los parámetros del haz, y se asume que el
cuadrimomento de la trayectoria proviene de un π+ (se asigna la masa del pión a la trayectoria). Con esto en
cuenta se procede a calcular la Missing Mass del evento, y se requiere que el valor obtenido no difiera en más
de 1000(MeV/c)2 con respecto (Mπ0c)2, para que este sea clasificado como evento válido.

5. Resultados

5.1. Mediciones obtenidas para K3π

Se esperaba que las distribuciones de la posición de decaimiento corregidas correspondieran a distribuciones
exponenciales. Como se mencionó con anterioridad, a las distribuciones obtenidas se les ajustó una exponencial
con dos parámetros libres, siendo uno de ellos el tiempo de vida τ . Uno de los parámetros para medir la cali-
dad del ajuste corresponde a χ2/ndf , expresión denominada chi cuadrada reducida. Este valor corresponde a una
medida de la discrepancia de la función a ajustar respecto a los datos dividido entre la cantidad de grados de
libertad existentes. Cuanto más se acerque este valor a la unidad, se dice entonces que la función ajustada describe
de buena manera a la distribución de los datos. En cambio, contar con valores por debajo de la unidad puede
indicar una sobre-estimación de las incertidumbres, mientras que contar con valores muy superiores a la unidad
indica que la función podría no ser la apropiada para describir la distribución de los datos. Además existe otro
valor, que nos da información acerca de la calidad del ajuste, el cual es el valor de probabilidad (p-value). Este valor
está contenido entre 0 y 1, tener valores altos de p indica que la función ajustada encaja correctamente con los datos.

Con la finalidad de aumentar la estadística y por consiguiente reducir el error estadístico inicialmente se realizó
el ajuste de la exponencial para los datos de K3π, entre los 105m a los 162.5m. No obstante, se obtuvo un valor
χ2/ndf = 3 y un valor p muy por debajo de la unidad, como puede apreciarse en la figura 40. Esto es un indicativo
de que la distribución total de la posición de decaimiento para este modo no corresponde a una exponencial. Esto
podría atribuirse a las altas incertidumbres en los últimos bins de la distribución, o bien, a algún tipo de error
sistemático.

5.4. Resumen de resultados
En el caso de K3π el resultado más favorable corresponde a un tiempo de vida de (12.63 ± 0.46)ns, con un

χ2/ndf = 1.18, teniendo este el error más bajo en el conjunto de mediciones cuyo valor de χ2 está cercano a la
unidad. No obstante, de los ajustes realizados en intervalos aledaños al intervalo de este ajuste, vemos fluctuaciones
considerables tanto en el tiempo de vida como en el χ2/ndf , como puede observarse en la tabla 7 y 8. Lo anterior, es
indicio de que el resultado obtenido en este modo de decaimiento podría no ser representativo del tiempo de vida.

Para K2π el resultado más favorable corresponde a (12.53 ± 0.25)ns con un χ2/ndf = 1.08, teniendo tanto el
error más bajo como el χ2/ndf mas cercano a la unidad de los intervalos estudiados. No obstante, y de forma similar
a K3π, los resultados obtenidos para otros intervalos de ajuste tienen variaciones considerables tanto en el tiempo
de vida obtenido como en χ2/ndf , como puede apreciarse en las tablas 9 y 10. Esto es indicio de la existencia de
un error sistemático, y por lo tanto el resultado obtenido no es concluyente.

El resultado más favorable de Kµ2 corresponde a (11.28 ± 0.25)ns con un χ2/ndf = 1.055, a diferencia de los
otros modos de decaimiento, las fluctuaciones en el tiempo de vida en otros intervalos no resultan distantes de este
valor, los valores están contenidos entre los (10.88 ± 0.41)ns y los (13.97 ± 1.97)ns, y sus valores de χ2/ndf son
cercanos y mayores a la unidad como puede apreciarse en la figura 45. El promedio de este conjunto de mediciones es
de (11.38± 0.10)ns y presentan una desviación estándar de 0.47ns. El cociente entre el tiempo de vida considerado
como más favorable respecto a la media es de 0.991± 0.024, siendo esto un indicio de que la medición considerada
es representativa de la muestra y por tanto buena candidata a tiempo de vida.

52



6. Conclusión y Trabajo a Futuro
Del presente estudio se concluye que tanto para el modo de decaimiento K2π como para K3π el método em-

pleado para obtener el tiempo de vida no es el más óptimo. Si bien se encontraron intervalos en los cuales el tiempo
de vida constaba de una incertidumbre baja, y el ajuste realizado satisfizo las pruebas estadísticas consideradas en
este análisis, las variaciones abruptas en el tiempo de vida tras variar el ancho del rango de ajuste ponen en duda la
validez de los resultados obtenidos. Esto es indicativo de la existencia de un error sistemático posiblemente presente
en la obtención de la aceptancia, pues es esta la distribución responsable de “corregir” la forma de la distribución
de la posición de decaimiento para los datos experimentales. En contraste, el modo de decaimiento Kµ2 presentó
una mayor cantidad de intervalos en los cuales el ajuste exponencial satisfizo las pruebas estadísticas realizadas y
además presento una menor fluctuación en los tiempos de vida obtenidos una vez que se varió el ancho del rango
de los ajustes, volviendo a estos resultados candidatos a tiempo de vida.

Las maneras en la que se obtuvieron las distribuciones de posición de decaimiento para K2π como Kµ2 son
bastante similares, puesto que tienen la misma topología de decaimiento, y los parámetros de selección entre los
eventos de un modo y el otro no son muy estrictos, diferenciándose principalmente en el valor de Missing Mass
requerido. Por lo tanto, podría inferirse que las notorias diferencias entre los resultados obtenidos para cada modo
recae mayoritariamente en la cantidad de eventos de cada uno. Sustento a lo anterior, es el diferente comporta-
miento de las distribuciones de similitud para ambos modos. Para Kµ2 la distribución aparenta tener secciones casi
constantes, las cuales contribuyen a que en los intervalos de ajuste, la desviación estándar de la similitud sea ba-
ja. Por el contrario, la distribución de similitud para K2π es decreciente y presenta fluctuaciones en su valor notorias.

De lo anterior, puede entonces plantearse que para mejorar los métodos empleados para obtener el tiempo de
vida con estos modos de decaimiento, puede optarse por el aumento en la estadística esto es realizar el análisis
pero incluyendo los datos tomados en años posteriores a los usados en este estudio, o bien, mejorar las simulaciones
realizadas con Monte Carlo. Siendo esta última opción de especial interés, pues mejoraría los resultados obtenidos
sin la necesidad de una mayor toma de datos, de lograrse esto también se mejorarían otros análisis que hagan uso
del mismo experimento.

abstracts.value:
In the present study the possibility of measuring the lifetime of the positively charged Kaon , K+, is investigated , by using data and framework produced by the experiment NA62 of the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN). Even though this experiment does not have as main goal the measurement of this charged meson‘s lifetime, it is the experiment with the best production of this particle, and the aquiered data can be employed for other studies.
The study was done by analyzing the 3 most common decay modes of the charged Kaon, corresponding to
K+ → μ + ν, K+ → π+ π0 , and K+ → π+ π+ π−. For each of them data and Monte Carlo simulations, done by the colaboration, were used. With this, acceptance, similarity between experiment and simulation,
and decay position distributions were obtained for each mode.
Finally it is concluded that for the decay modes K+ → π+ π0 and K+ → π+ π +π−, obtaining the lifetime is unfeasible with the current resources; while for the decay mode K+ →μ+ + ν feasible results were obtained. To get improvements in the measurement results of the three decay modes, further studies
are required to determine possible systematic errors in the Monte Carlo simulations.

1.1. General introduction

This first Part aims at a general introduction to the history, theories and phenomena at
stake in the physics of cosmic rays. The current Chapter reviews some of the discoveries
of the first half of the Twentieth Century that gave birth to some of the branches of
Physics which the rest of this work deals with, without of course pretending to stand
among them. Chapter 2 uses the tools of modern cosmology to exhibit some evidences of
the existence of dark matter, along with some physical mechanisms which could lead to
its eventual indirect detection by particle detectors in space. The hasty reader can skip
without qualms both Chapters, since their content won’t be directly used in the core

1.2. Small clouds in a clear sky

1.2.1. The dawn of the twentieth century

The end of the nineteenth century is often considered as a time where many physicists
thought their discipline was near to its end [Wró06]. We can quote the French chemist
Marcellin Berthelot, who wrote in 1885 [Ber85] “Le monde est aujourd’hui sans mystère”

(the world is now without mystery) or Albert A. Michelson, who said in 1903 [Mic03]:

“The more important fundamental laws and facts of physical science have all
been discovered, and these are now so firmly established that the possibility of
their ever being supplanted in consequence of new discoveries is exceedingly
remote [...] Our future discoveries must be looked for in the sixth place of
decimals”

The most famous citation, however, probably comes from the introduction of a lecture
made by Lord Kelvin in 1900 [Kel01], reproduced in Figure 1.1. The extensive quote
reads:

“The beauty and clearness of the dynamical theory, which asserts heat and
light to be modes of motion, is at present obscured by two clouds. I. The first
came into existence with the undulatory theory of light, and was dealt with by
Fresnel and Dr. Thomas Young; it involved the question, how could the earth
move through an elastic solid, such as essentially is the luminiferous ether?
II. The second is the Maxwell-Boltzmann doctrine regarding the partition of
energy.”

1.2.2. Einstein’s Annus Mirabilis

The two clouds he is referring to will respectively lead to the development of the special
relativity and the quantum mechanics, mostly triggered by two articles of Albert Einstein

1.2.3. The discharge of the electroscope

Some other small “clouds”, however, proved to have great further development. Among
the phenomena which were not explained, was the progressive loss of charge in the
electroscope, a device used to measure the rate of ion production inside a hermetically
sealed container. About that time, electroscopes are constituted by two thin conductive
foils suspended at an electrode. When the electrode is charged, the foils carry a charge
of same sign and are pushed apart; the greater the charge, the further they go, so that a
measurement of the distance between them gives a direct estimation of electrode’s charge.
However, although isolated from ground, the electroscopes loss their charge through time,
which tends to indicate that the discharge is made through the air. On the other hand,
air is known to be an excellent electric insulator, keeping open to the question of the
discharge.

A first element of answer came in 1896 (before Einstein’s articles). At that time,
the recent equations of Maxwell seemed to indicate that light was rather made of
electromagnetic waves than particles. However, that year, the french physicist Antoine
Henri Becquerel discovered, by studying phosphorescent elements, that uranium salts
emitted radiations able to discharge electrical materials far from the source [Béc96]. He
established that those emitted rays increased the conductivity of gas through the creation
of new charge carriers he named ions. Pierre and Marie Curie discovered that polonium
and radium emitted these radiations as well, and coined the term radioactivity.

In 1897, Sir Joseph John Thomson proved that the electric charge is carried by
particles, that he named corpuscles [Tho97]. These new particles had the same charge
as the hydrogen atom, but a e/m ratio 1700 times greater. This will be a great success
both for the understanding of electricity and, along with the discovery of radioactivity,



10 Chapter 1. Milestones of Physics in the early twentieth century

for the atomic model. A few years later, in 1911, Robert Millikan would identify these
new particles with the electrons and measure their absolute charge.

The explanation of the discharge of the electroscope wass finally given in 1900 by
two German physicists: Julius Elster and Hans Geitel [EG00]. They showed that the
discharge was significantly more important at an altitude of 3 km than on ground. By
proving that the ionization of the air was the same phenomenon as the ionization from
gas having been in contact with radioactive substances, they could conclude that a sort
of natural radioactivity constituted the source of ionization in the atmosphere and of the
electric discharge of charged conductors.

Figure 1.3.: Wulf’s Strahlunsapparat

In 1909, Theodor Wulf created a new electroscope, the Strahlungsapparat, by replacing
the foils by two conducting wires, attached at the top and the bottom, see Figure 1.3. A
microscope combined with a micrometer allowed to measure the distance between the two
wires in the middle with an unmatched precision. Despite Elster and Geitel observations,
it was widely believed that the natural radiation from ground was the source of the
electroscope discharge. Wulf predicted that if he moved far enough from those sources,
less radiation would be detected, advising to do balloon-bourne experiments [Wul09],
and tested himself the hypothesis in 1910 by comparing the radiation at the top and
bottom of the Eiffel Tower. Knowing the absorption coefficient of the air, it was expected,
at a 80 m height, half the discharge value with respect to that on ground, and nearly
no radiation on top (330 m) of the Eiffel tower. He found that the ionization fell from



1.3. The discovery of cosmic rays 11

6 ions cm−3 s−1 on ground to 3.5 ions cm−3 s−1 on top of the Eiffel tower, in contrast with
the almost-null expected value [Wul10]. He concluded that one had either to expect an
extra source of gamma-rays in the atmosphere, or a smaller absorption coefficient in air.

1.3. The discovery of cosmic rays

1.3.1. Victor Hess and the “radiation from above”

In 1910 and 1911, two flights between 300 and 2800 m were made by the German physicist
Albert Gockel; he found that the radiation seemed to increase at high altitudes, but
stated his conclusions with great doubts. In 1911 Domenico Pacini observed simultaneous
variations of the rate of ionization over a lake, over the sea, and at a depth of 3 m from
the surface. Pacini concluded from the decrease of radioactivity underwater that a certain
part of the ionization had to be due to sources other than the radioactivity of the Earth
[Pac12].

The real pushing forward was made by Victor Hess. Before 1911, the absorption
coefficient in air had never been measured, what he did by using radioactive substances
placed at various distances of a Wulf electrometer, finding 4.47 × 10−5 cm−1 (the density
law predicted 4.4 × 10−5 cm−1).

To test the other hypothesis, Hess decided to do a series of flights in balloons. He
disposed of a Strahlungsapparat specifically developed by Wulf for measurements at high
altitude and underwater. He made a total of nine flights, the seven last of them taking
place between April and August 1912, to an altitude up to 5300 m. The last, and most
famous, of them, took place the seventh of August, 1912, during a near-total eclipse to
rule out the Sun as radiation source. Figure 1.4 shows him a few weeks before this flight.

The conclusions were the following: the ionization radiation decreases steady up to
an altitude of about 1600 m, after which in increases up to 5300 m, where the amount of
radiation has doubled, showing that penetrating radiation is entering the atmosphere
from a source other than the Sun. Hess called the radiation Höhenstrahlung, radiation
from above.

Those results were confirmed in 1913 and 1914 by Werner Kolhörster, who noted an
increase in the ionization up to an altitude of 9300 m.

1.3.2. The nature of Cosmic Rays

In 1926, the term cosmic rays was coined by Robert Millikan who had made measurements
of ionization due to cosmic rays from deep under water to high altitudes and around the
globe. Millikan believed his measurements proved that the primary cosmic rays were
energetic photons, and proposed a theory explaining their formation in interstellar space
as by-products of the fusion of hydrogen atoms into heavier elements.

On the other hand, scientists like Compton believed that the cosmic rays were charged
particles. A famous controversy opposed the two scientists, doing the front page of
newspaper, see Figure 1.5. The evidence supporting the latter theory was brought by J.
Clay, who found evidence in 1927 of a variation of cosmic ray intensity with latitude,
which indicated that the primary cosmic rays are deflected by the geomagnetic field and
should therefore be charged particles, not photons [Cla27].

In 1928, Johannes Geiger and his student Walter Müller invented the Geiger-Müller
counter who could measure all sort of ionizing radiation. Walter Bothe, who had assisted
Geiger in 1924, got interested in the cosmic rays. Using two Geiger-Müller counters to



1.3. The discovery of cosmic rays 13

Figure 1.5.: First page of the New-York Times from December 31, 1932

probe for coincidences, they proved that the gamma rays were not the main source of
cosmic rays.

In 1934, Bruno Rossi found that the intensity of cosmic rays is greater from the West,
proving that most primaries are positive. Observing that the rate of near-simultaneous
discharges of two widely-separated Geiger counters was larger than the expected accidental
rate, he wrote in his report on the experiment [Ros34]:

“it seems that once in a while the recording equipment is struck by very
extensive showers of particles, which causes coincidences between the counters,
even placed at large distances from one another.”

In 1938, the French physicist Pierre Auger, unaware of Rossi’s earlier report, detected
the same phenomenon and investigated it in some detail. He made coincidence studies
using two groups of counters separated by distances going from 2 to 300 m, both at
the ground level, and at altitudes of 3500 m (Jungfraujoch) and 2900 m (Pic du Midi).
[Aug+39]. He showed the existence of cosmic rays showers of great surface, and made
an evaluation of their energy to estimate the energy of the primary particle, greater



14 Chapter 1. Milestones of Physics in the early twentieth century

than 1015 eV. He concluded that high-energy primary cosmic-ray particles interact with
air nuclei high in the atmosphere, initiating a cascade of secondary interactions that
ultimately yields a shower of electrons, and photons that reach ground level.

1.3.3. Thematic displacement

Before the invention of particle accelerators, cosmic rays became an effective way to
discover and study high-energy particles. The fog chamber, invented by Charles Wilson
in 1911, was combined with a magnet by Anderson and Millikan, allowing to test for
the composition of those cosmic rays. In 1932, Anderson discovered particles behaving
like electrons but of opposite curvature sign, therefore of opposite charge [And33]. They
were identified with positrons (e+), the antiparticle of electron predicted by Paul Dirac a
few years earlier [Dir28]. For this discovery, Anderson received in 1936 the Nobel Prize
in Physics, a prize he shared with Hess for the discovery of the extraterrestrial origin of
the cosmic rays.

In the following decades, and with the progress of fog chambers, many particles would
be discovered, among them the muon in 1936 [Mil39], the pion in 1947 [LOP47], and, the
same year, the kaons [RB47]. Starting from 1953, the particle physicists moved from the
study of cosmic rays to the newly-created particle accelerators, and then colliders. The
cosmic rays became a research field by themselves, aimed at studying the composition
and origin of these astroparticles.

1.4. From General Relativity to the Big-Bang

1.4.1. Relativities

The four articles published by Albert Einstein in 1905 (see Section 1.2.2), through the
introduction of new symmetries (of energy exchanges, of independence of the observer),
changed deeply the way the world was perceived, by redefining concepts such as time
and space.

However, the special relativity was not compatible with the Newtonian theory of
gravitation, which described the gravitational interaction as instantaneous, whereas
Einstein’s special relativity stated that nothing could go faster than the speed of light in



1.4. From General Relativity to the Big-Bang 15

vacuum. Moreover, the underlying concept of simultaneity of the two events, depending
on the observer, was not compatible with the global vision of Einstein, based on the
symmetry of the observer.

Einstein began working on the subject in 1907 and presented his theory of General
Relativity in 1915 [Ein15]. The general concept is that the Universe is in a non-euclidian
space-time, whose local curvature, Gµν , is relied to the mass-energy contents of the
universe, Tµν , through:

Gµν = 8πGTµν (1.4.1)

It correctly described the precession of Mercury apside, which was by then unexplained,
providing a strong argument in favor of the theory.

Recombination and decoupling

After nucleosynthesis, the Universe is constituted of protons, helium, photons, and

practically embedded into matter, and interact with it through pressure waves (baryonic
acoustic oscillations, or BAO).

Around 1 eV electrons and protons begin to form a significant amount of hydrogen,
causing the photons do drop out of equilibrium. Those decoupled photons, with a
mean free path now infinite, continue their trajectory until today, and form the Cosmic

Microwave Background, or CMB, which can be detected, due to space dilatation, at a
lowered temperature of 2.71 K.

The matter, on its side, aggregates into large-scale structures. The pressure waves
have stopped at the same radius; in terms of angular distributions, the statistical distance
between two structures will reflect this radius. Similarly, the CMB has inhomogeneities,
and the statistical distance between two of them, along with the radius the BAO reached
at the time of recombinaison, allow us to fix all the parameters previously discussed.

2.2.2. Bullet cluster

The 1E 0657-56, as known as bullet cluster, results from the collision of two galaxy
clusters. Its study began in 2003 [Mar+03], and was completed, many by the same team,
in 2006 [Clo+06]. The cluster has two visible components. Hot gases, which can be
observed through X-rays, account for most of the baryonic mass of the cluster. Their
interaction in the collision slows them down. The other component of ordinary matter
are the stars, whose light make them visible. Contrary to the gases, they interact mostly
gravitationally, and are less slowed down than gases. The total mass distribution of the
cluster can be estimated through the effect of gravitational lensing. Figure 2.2 shows a

of the mass contained within the cluster is not in the baryonic distribution, and did not
interact as much as the gas. It is a evidence of dark matter made of (weakly-interacting)
particles, which can not be fully accounted by alternative missing mass models such as
MOND (MOdified Newton Dynamics).

2.3. Candidates and detection

2.3.1. First candidates

Dark Matter constitutes a large fraction of the energy in the Universe. So far, thanks to
Planck results, it is only known that it is not baryonic matter. This Section reviews the
main candidates to Dark Matter.

The first candidate that can be thought of is a class of exotic objects, like planets
or stars, but not made of ordinary matter, and too dark or small to be seen. This class
is referred as MAssive Compact Halo Objects, or MACHOs. Primordial Black Holes
(PBHs), formed by some violent epochs in Big Bang, could be good candidates. For
PMHs created during the radiation-dominated universe, causality considerations show
that their mass must be lighter than 1000 solar masses, and, on the other hand, heavier
than 10−16 solar masses, otherwise they would emit a visible Hawking radiation [Mur07].
The MACHO and EROS collaborations have estimated the possible amount of MACHOs
in our galactic halo through the study of microlensing effects in the Large Magellan
Cloud, concluding that MACHOs of 10−7 to 30 solar masses can not account for the
Dark Matter in our galactic halo [Tis+06].

Other primer candidates have been neutrinos, which were already ruled out, CHAMPs
(CHArged Massive Particles), and Strongly Interacting Massive Particles (SIMPs), the
two latter being excluded as shown, respectively, in [Dim+90] and [Sta+90]. That brings
back to the study of WIMPs, not made of baryonic matter. The next Section, after a
review of the standard model, will try to show how the supersymmetry could provide a
valuable candidate to those WIMPs.

R-Parity and LSP

The symmetry introduced with no further constraints would give, in Feynman diagrams,
vertices with couplings in the order of the unity, leading to a proton lifetime of about
10−12 s (the actual lifetime is longer than 1.6 × 1033 y). A new symmetry, the R-parity,
has to be added, such that

Rp ≡ (−1)3B+L+2s = (−1)matterR2π (2.3.4)

Where B is the baryon number, L the lepton number, and s the spin. For quarks and
squarks, B = 1/3, and L = 0, but while for the primer s = 1/2, for the latter s = 0,
leading respectively to R-parities of +1 and −1. More generally, particles with odd
R-parity (such that RP = −1) are the supersymmetric particles (or sparticles), and
particles with even R-parity (RP = 1) are the particles of the standard model.

This has several consequences:

• The previous phenomenon is avoided, leading to the stability of the protons.

• In collider experiments, sparticles can only be produced in even numbers (usually
by pairs).

• The sparticles can only decay into a state containing an odd number of sparticles of
smaller mass, escaping the detectors with a missing momentum signature.

• The lightest supersymmetric particle, from now on referred as LSP, cannot decay. In
most models, it also turns out to be electrically neutral. The LSP could constitute
a good candidate for Dark Matter.

Indirect

The second class of experiments tries to identify dark matter candidates through the

3.1.1. Introduction

This Section comes back to the cosmic rays described in Section 1.3. They are described,
with a particular focus on theirs fluxes, and in the light of the results of recent experiments.
Cosmic ray protons, electrons, their antiparticles and nuclei are the only charged particles
which have been detected from sources outside the Solar System. Among the particles
composing the overall flux at the top of the atmosphere, 87 % are protons, 12 % are

antiprotons. The ratio of antiprotons and protons is about 2 × 10−4 at 10 − 20 GeV. If
the focus is made in the region of 1012 eV to 1015 eV, the composition changes to about
50 % of protons, 25 % of helium, 13 % of carbon, nitrogen and oxygen (called CNO), and
13 % of iron [Sok04].

3.1.2. Overall spectrum

In the first order, the previous ratios apply for protons, electrons, their respective
antiparticles, gamma-rays, and nuclei until 1014 eV. It is in agreement with the spectrum
of high energy particles inferred to be present in galactic and extragalactic non-thermal
radio sources, and can be linked to the relativistic gas expected in the interstellar medium
through the synchrotron radiation of ultra-relativistic electrons gyrating in the interstellar
medium field detected in the radio waveband, and the galactic gamma-ray emission above
100 MeV. It tends to indicate that the cosmic-ray particles detected at the top of the
atmosphere are a good sample of high-energy particles pervading the interstellar medium.

The effective study of charged cosmic rays began in the 1960s when the first satellites
carrying cosmic-ray particle detectors were sent into space. They could determine the
first characteristics of the cosmic rays, whose overall spectrum is shown in Figure 3.1.
What follows goes into the detail of the spectrum, but first of all, for energies above
100 − 1000 MeV, it can be seen that the total spectrum of cosmic-ray particles can be
described by a power law going as

N(E)dE = KE−γdE (3.1.1)

where γ, called the spectral index of the flux, goes from 2.5 to 3 approximately.

We can separate the spectrum into three zones:

• For the lower energies (below 1 GeV/nucleon) a cutoff of the spectrum can be seen.

• Between 109 eV and 1015 eV, γ ≈ 2.5 − 2.7; concerning the rates, at 1011 eV, for
example, 1 particle m−2 s−1 can be observed.

• At 1015 eV, a bump, called the knee, is visible; the rate is 1 particle m−2 year−1.

• After the knee, the spectrum steepens with a spectral index of about 3.2.

Below 1 GeV/nucleon

Below about 1 GeV/nucleon, the cosmic rays spectra exhibit a cutoff, due to the Solar
Wind. Indeed, the cosmic-ray particles diffuse in towards the Earth from interstellar
space through the outflowing wind, and the propagation of the particles of lesser energy
is therefore impeded. The solar activity has a cycle of 11 years on average; the beginning
of the last cycle, corresponding to minima in irradiance, number of sun spots observed,
and solar flares, took place in December 2008. During a cycle, the energy and shape
of the cutoff vary so that the fluxes of low-energy particles decrease during periods of
high solar activity and are at a maximum during low solar activity. This phenomenon is
called solar modulation.

The p̄/p ratio shows a strong dependence on the phase and polarity of the solar cycle
in the opposite sense to that of the positron fraction, suggesting that the antiparticles

When they interact with matter, be it the Earth atmosphere or the subdetectors of a

For the particles produced:

• The secondary nucleons and pions produced initiate other showers until the energy

• The protons lose energy by ionization until they reach an energy of 1 GeV, where

• The charged pions have a lifetime of 2.551 × 10−8 s and decay mostly into muons, re-

decay into electrons, antineutrinos and muons neutrinos, along with their respective
antiparticles. Once again, the electrons and positrons produce electromagnetic
showers, as described in Section 3.2.3.

Finally, the hadronic showers develop somewhat similarly to the electromagnetic ones.

3.3. Recent results from cosmic-ray detectors

In the light of what precedes, and depending on the goals searched for, compromises
have to be done to study the cosmic rays:

• Because of their interaction with the atmosphere, the direct study of charged cosmic
rays must be done above it. This can either be done with balloon-borne (Cream,
Bess, Heat...), or space (AMS-02, PAMELA...) experiments. However, to get enough
statistics, due to the flux, and the limited surface available in space (in the order of
the square meter, for, say, a ten-year experiment), values above a few TeV can not
be expected.

• Reciprocally, the study of charged cosmic rays of higher energy (up to the GZK cut)
can only be done on ground experiments (AUGER), where the available surface is
not a concern. The atmosphere is used as a calorimeter, at the cost of the direct
study of primary particles.

• In the same manner, the photons at the TeV and above are studied through their
development into atmospheric showers (MAGIC, HESS, CTA...).

• Low-energy gamma rays can only be studied directly in space, for example by
EGRET from 30 MeV to 30 GeV.

From now on, the focus is made on the AMS-02 detector, with the aim of determining
the positron fraction. Towards this goal, the main results of the recent experiments
are recalled. The first crucial result was obtained by the PAMELA experiment in 2008
[Adr+08] (with an update in [Adr+13]), and is shown in Figure 3.9. If the positrons
were only secondary particles, a decrease of this ratio with the increasing energy would
have been expected. The increasing of the ratio after 10 GeV was the first evidence of a
primary source of positrons.

4.1. Introduction and objectives

The Alpha Magnetic Spectrometer–02 (from now on AMS-02), is a particle physics
detector, more precisely a magnetic spectrometer, installed on the International Space
Station on May 2011, after a construction going from 1999 to 2010. After a year of
commissioning at Kennedy Space Center, the instrument was launched on May 16th,
2011, on board of the shuttle flight STS-134, lead by Mark Kelly, the penultimate mission
of NASA’s Space Shuttle program, and last spaceflight of space shuttle Endeavour The
detector was then delivered to the International Space Station, being handled from the
shuttle cargo bay with the shuttle’s robotic arm and handed off to the station’s robotic

63



64 Chapter 4. The AMS-02 experiment

arm for installation. AMS-02 has taken data since May 19th, during all time (including
over the South Atlantic Anomaly), and is expected to continue through the lifetime of
ISS, that is, at least until 2020. In June 2013, 35 billion events were recorded, with a
total of 300 billions expected during its 20 years lifetime.

A schematic view of the instrument can be seen in Figure 4.1, and Table 4.1 details
some of the reference values of the data taken on the ISS. Due to the Earth magnetic
field, the particle rates are much greater near the magnetic poles. Several subdetectors
of AMS-02 require regular calibrations, and to avoid saturation, those calibrations are
made near the equator, where the rate is lower. An orbit of the ISS lasts for 1.5 h, and
will cross four times the equator. The data taken from AMS-02 are grouped into runs
of approximately 22 min (four by orbit); every other run, when the detector is at the
equator (where the particle flux is lower), a 3 s calibration run is taken.

Figure 4.1.: Schematic view of the AMS-02 detector

The main goal of AMS-02 is to identify the nature of the cosmic particles coming from
space, and determine their precise fluxes. Following the results reviewed in Section 3,
AMS-02 will detect particles before their interaction in the atmosphere, in energy ranges
going from the GeV to the TeV scales. The main particles fluxes observed will be those of
protons, electrons, deuterons, nuclei up to the iron (Z=26), their respective antiparticles,
and gamma-rays. This will serve the following purposes.

Dark matter studies As was said in Section 2.3.5, dark-matter interaction or anni-
hilation could create primary fluxes of particles detectable by AMS-02. However, a
signal could hardly be seen in the particles which already have the most important
fluxes, namely protons and electrons, but could be expected in positrons, antiprotons,
or antideuterons fluxes. AMS-02 has been designed to precisely identify the particles,
along with their charge, and reject the background fluxes. Chapter 7 to Chapter 9 are
dedicated to the quantification of that identification.

Search for primordial antimatter The standard models in particles physics and cos-
mology, previously reviewed, along with the fluxes composition, share the idea of a
highly-asymmetric universe towards baryon, by introducing mechanisms such as CP -
parity violation. However, some models state that the Universe could be symmetric.
Under that hypothesis, there would be creation of nuclei such as He during the nucleosyn-
thesis, which can not be produced by any other known phenomenon, including spallation,
and should be primordial. The detection of only one of those nuclei (allowed by the
great acceptance of the detector) would lead to a major change in the standard model
of cosmology. Moreover, the primordial nucleosynthesis could not create nuclei heavier
than Lithium (Z=3). Would AMS-02 detect a single nucleus of anti-carbon, it would

4.3. Transition Radiation Detector (TRD)

The main goal of the TRD is to identify relativistic particles through the detection of
the X-rays emitted by electrons and protons in the subdetector. When a relativistic
charged particle crosses the interface of two media having different dielectric constants,
it emits an optical transition radiation whose energy increases with the Lorentz factor,
γ = E/mc2 and directed forward, peaking at an angle in the order of 1/γ relative to the
particles path.

At a given energy, a lighter particle, such as an electron, will have a high Lorentz
factor while a heavier one, such as a hadron, will have a lower γ and will radiate much



4.3. Transition Radiation Detector (TRD) 69

less. The photons are visible by the detector for γ > 103, the threshold being reached for
the protons above 300 GeV/c. This characteristics will allow for a discrimination between
both types of particles, particularly in the range 1 − 100 GeV. The emitted photons have
energies typically in the range from 2 to 20 keV, with a low interaction probability of
1 % for particles having γ = 2.103, therefore the need to use several layers of alternating
materials to collect enough photons for an adequate measurement.

Practically, the TRD is composed of 328 modules, each containing a 20 mm thick
radiator and 16 tube straws [KS04]. The modules are arranged in 20 layers, the 4 on top
and bottom are parallels to the magnetic field of the magnet, and the 12 central layers
are perpendicular to it, allowing a three-dimensional reconstruction of the track. The
radiator is made of a collection of polypropylene/polyethylene 10 µm thick fiber fleeces,
corresponding to a density of 0.06 g cm−3, and providing 200 index changes. The straws
are filled with a 90 % Xe – 10 % CO2 gas mixture operating at 1600 V.

Figure 4.3 shows the physical mechanism: the mixture converts the X-rays passing
through the fibers. The ionized gas will start an ionization avalanche, whose contribution
will add up to the normal ionization due to a charged particle crossing the gas, and be
collected at the end of the straws. Due to the high threshold for the heavier particles,
which only have the normal ionization contribution, the TRD will allow to discriminate
efficiently between electrons and hadrons. The rejection power1 ranges from 102 to 103,
up to 300 GeV [KS04] for a 90 % efficiency. Above 300 GeV, the Lorentz factor of protons
becomes comparable to the one of electrons, thus reducing the separation power.

4.4. Time-of-Flight System (ToF)

The ToF system serves several purposes [Alv+99; Bin+13]:

• Be the first level trigger of the experiment for charged particles.

• Give the direction (downstream / upstream) of those particles.

• Separate between e+/e− and p/p̄ up to 2 GeV.

• Measure the absolute charge of the incident particle.

The subdetector is made of polyvinyltoluene scintillator paddles of rectangular or
trapezoidal shape having approximate dimensions of 1 × 12 × 120 cm3. The paddles are
arranged by planes, numbered from 1 to 4: the planes 1 and 2 (Upper ToF, or UToF),
consisting of 8 paddles each, are located above the magnet, and the planes 3 and 4
(Lower ToF, LToF), consisting of respectively 10 and 8 planes, are below the magnet.
The planes 1 and 3 are aligned along the X coordinate, and the planes 2 and 4 along the
Y coordinate, allowing a raw localisation of the particle. The scintillators are coupled at
both ends via plexiglass light guides to 4 or 6 photomultipliers.

The ToF measures precisely the time difference between the Upper and Lower ToF,
with a timing resolution of 160 ps for protons and and 48 ps for carbon [Bin+13]. The
distance between the two pairs of planes is of 1.2 m, leading, for a particle having a β

close to the unity, to a time of several nanoseconds to go from the Upper to the Lower
ToF. The system has a resolution on the speed of particles of 4 % for H, 2 % for He,
and 1.2 % for C [Bin+13], and can efficiently distinguish the direction of the incident
particle with a rejection of 109, avoiding confusion between matter downgoing particles
and antimatter upgoing particles. It also allows to distinguish positrons from protons in
the rigidity range 0.5 to 2 GV and protons from ions up to R ≈ 3.5 GV.

4.7. Electromagnetic Calorimeter (ECAL)

4.7.1. Layout

The Electronic CALorimeter is a three-dimensional imaging calorimeter composed of a
sandwich of 9 superlayers. Each superlayer consists of scintillating silicium fibers with
a diameter of 1 mm inserted in 11 lead leaves with a thickness of 1.68 mm, for a total
thickness of 18.5 mm.

The light guided inside the fibers is collected at one end of them by 4-anode photomul-
tipliers Hamamatsu R7600 00-M4. Each PMT (dynode) consists of two pixels in height
and two in width, for a total of 4 anodes. A picture of a PMT, along with its schematized
position on the calorimeter, can be seen in Figure 4.17. Each superlayer will, then, be
split into two layers in height, for a total of 18 layers. To avoid dead zones, the PMT are
alternatively distributed at each end of the fibers. Each superlayer is instrumented by 36



80 Chapter 4. The AMS-02 experiment

PMT (18 on each side), defining two layers in height and 36 × 2 = 72 cells in width. The
is a total of 9 superlayers, for 324 PMT and 1296 pixels (anodes).

Figure 4.17.: Schematic picture of a PMT and of its position in the ECAL

Each fiber, taken individually, can’t give any information about the position where
it was hit, so that each superlayer gives only an unidirectional information on what
cell was hit. Therefore, the superlayers alternate in X and Y directions, allowing a
3D reconstruction of the shower by interpolation between two consecutive planes. The
alternated structure of the ECAL before instrumentation can be seen in Figure 4.18.
The active surface is 648 × 648 mm.

4.7.2. Electronic readout

The energy deposited in the fibers has to be converted to a digital signal convenient
for our purposes which, in agreement with the general layout of AMS-02 subdetectors,
is done through Analog-to-Digital Converters (ADC), which give an integer number of
counts. The effective data in ECAL ADC are computed by subtracting the values of

4.7.4. Performance

For the ECAL, quantitative values have been precisely measured in 2007 [Ros12]. The
critical energy has a value of EC ≈ 7.6 ± 0.2 MeV,. The calorimeter depth has been
estimated to 1.05 ± 0.02 layer unit, which amounts to a total of 17.1 radiation lengths
(X0) [GR08]. For 1 TeV electrons, it leads to 16 % leakage and a shower maximum
expected in layer 11. It was possible, by measuring the position of the maximum of the
longitudinal profile both in beam tests and ISS data, to estimate the amount of material
in front of the calorimeter, measured to be around 0.7 ± 0.1X0.

In the ECAL, λ has been found to be of 25.75 cm, (26.6 X0, 28 layers) [Ros12]. For
a 10 GeV proton the shower maximum is settled at 21 cm, beyond the dimensions of
the calorimeter. With T the length of the calorimeter, the interaction probability of a
hadronic shower in the calorimeter is given by

P = 1 − e−T/λ ≃ 1 − e−0.75 = 0.5 (4.7.1)

The corresponding theoretical curve is drawn in Figure 4.40. It means that about half
of the protons do not develop a shower inside the ECAL, and deposit a trace without
lateral dispersion. These are the MIPs described in Section 3.2.4, which will be widely
used in Chapter 5, for instance to recompute the value of λ.

4.7.5. Conclusion on the Electronic CALorimeter

In conclusion, the whole of the front-end electronics is still working; two PMTs are
missing, among which one after the launch; there is no noise and the performance is
steady. The next Chapter will elaborate on the stability of the ECAL, the variation of
the MIPs with the temperature, and the aging effects.

4.8. Anti-Coincidence Counter (ACC)

The ACC works as a veto for charged particles that are not in the acceptance of the
detector (typically: horizontal ones) and for secondary particles resulting from the
interaction of primary cosmic rays with the detector environment (magnet, aluminum
honeycomb...) which produce jets of particles. It allows to discard 80 % of these particles
[BW07]. The Figure 4.41 shows schematically three cases of figure.

The ACC is composed of 16 vertical scintillating paddles of 10 mm thickness located
between the inner tracker and the permanent magnet. Photomultipliers read the light at
both end of paddles.

is rejected. On the central panel, an incoming ion traversing matter produces δ-
rays electrons, case for which the veto is disabled. On the right panel, backsplash
particles produced from an e−/e+ conversion in the ECAL, allowed by the
trigger condition “ToF and not more than 4 ACC paddles fired”.

4.9. Star Tracker and GPS

Although the timespace position of the ISS is well known, the precision of its measure
is not sufficient enough to match the one required by AMS. There are two additional
subdetectors which take it into account.

The position of the AMS-02 is determined by the precise position of the photons
received. The ECAL and Tracker (via pair conversion) can monitor their arrival. The
Star Tracker determines with more precision than the ISS the orientation of the station.
Knowing the position of fixed stars, it will allow to precisely determine the direction of
incoming photons. It is composed of two CCD digital photographic cameras taking every
10 s a pictures of the sky with a field of view of 6◦, which, when compared to stellar
maps, indicates the orientation of AMS.

The GPS determines the precise time where a gamma-ray has arrived, which is
important due to the variability of sources. It gives a GPS UTC time combined with a
fine-time measurement of an AMS DAQ internal clock to give the precise arrival date of
the particle.

4.10. Electronics

The electronics gathers all signals through 650 electronic boards for a total of about
300 000 channels, equivalent to all of the ISS electronics channels combined [CC03]. All



4.10. Electronics 97

of the boards are installed in several copies to get a full redundancy in case of failure of
one or several boards. Their role goes from power supply to Data Acquisition (DAQ).
The main system is the JMDC (Main DAQ Computer), with a four-copy redundancy,
which sends commands and receives replies from all boards.

The subdetectors have a unified approach for their electronics. The signals coming
from the detectors are digitized through an Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC), which
gives an integer number of counts. The signal is then reduced through Data Reduction
(DR) boards (for example EDR for ECAL). The JINF receives up to 24 DR boards,
buffers and sends their signal to the top-level JINJ boards, which in turn aggregate,
buffer and send the data to the JMDC, which evaluates whether the event is good or
not. In the primer case, the event is sent through the High-Rate Dynamic Link (HRDL)
as soon as they are available, due to the station position with respect to satellites.

5.1.3. Span

Not all the MIPs share the same properties. Vertical MIPs will cross a length of matter
equal to h = 17 cm, while particles impinging with an angle θ with respect to the vertical
z axis will cross a length equal to h/ cos(θ). In each cell, with an increasing θ, more
matter is crossed, depositing more energy, since the energy is proportional to the length
of fiber crossed. So, by integrating over all particles of different angles, the energy
distribution is shifted towards the high energies, and its spread is increased. Depending
on the application required (more precise measurements, or statistics), compromises have
to be made on the selection.

The present approach defines the span as following. If Cx,0 and Cy,0 are the coordinates,
expressed in cells, and interpolated, of the entry point of a particle in the calorimeter, a
particle having a span of s will, for each layer l before the apex, be such that |S1l−Cx/y,0| <

s, where Cx/y,0 is the entry coordinate relevant to the direction of the layer considered.
For example, a span of 1 corresponds to MIPs for which all the cells in x and y, share
the same coordinate, that is, vertical particles. What follows details how much data can
expected for protons with ISS data at a given span, but to give an order of idea, for one
cell a span of 3 provides sufficient statistics for one 22 min run, and a span of 1 for one
day.

5.1.4. Interlude: interaction length determination

We recall that the probability for a vertical proton to interact in the ECAL after n layers
is given by P = 1 − e−n/λ, see Figure 4.40. Reciprocally, by determining the position of
the apex (in layers) of the protons crossing the ECAL with a span of 1, and drawing
the normalized distribution of these positions, λ can be estimated. This is, in fact, the
method which, as described in [Ros12], was contributed to be developped to precisely
determine λ. The fraction of protons having not interacted (1 − P ), shown in Figure 5.6,
is fitted with a function e−n/λ, to find λ ≈ 28, which represents about 1.56 radiation
lengths.

5.5. Aging effects measurements

5.5.1. Objectives

The MIP particles, once correctly corrected for attenuation and equalization, offer a
stable probe and can be used to monitor the evolution of the PMTs over a large span of
time, thus allowing to test for effects such as aging, check for dead PMTs, etc. However,
contrary to the beam tests where it was controlled and stable, in space the temperature
varies over time. In particular, the temperature changes affect the electronics, at different
levels: the front-end electronics, but also the power supplies (high and low voltage).

Figure 5.25 shows the evolution of the MIP signal (parameter Max of the fit) for the
Starboard and of the temperature sensor DS12, located in the middle of the Starboard
side. We can see that the two of them are highly negatively correlated (high temperatures
correspond to high MIP Max values and vice versa.) In this Section, after detailing
the MIP selection, this effect is quantified, the MIPs are corrected in each cell from any
temperature effects, and possible aging effects are checked.

Figure 5.25.: MIP (blue, right-axis scale) and Temperature (black, left-axis scale) evolution
for Starboard side. MIP values have been smoothed to keep two points per day.



5.5. Aging effects measurements 125

5.5.2. MIP selection

As was discussed earlier, the mean statistics per cell is primordial to correctly assess
the MIP Max value with sufficient precision, and a minimum of 1000 hits/cell should be
expected. In what follows, a span of 3 is taken to increase the statistics while keeping a
low dispersion in path length, what gives a mean statistics of 2000 − 2500 hits/cell/day.
Although this value is sufficient to keep a daily measurement, due to the difference
of exposition to the sunlight, the temperatures have a variation period well below the
day. If pedestals (and then MIP values) are, as expected, strongly correlated to the
temperatures, a period shorter than the day must be considered.

A first idea has been to “sum up” the cells belonging to the same EHV and fit the
resulting distribution. As expected, after attenuation and equalization corrections, all
the cells share the same distributions. The problem is that, although both Gaussian
and Landau distributions are stable (and the sum of cells is distributed like a Landau
convoluted with a Gaussian), it is difficult to predict the exact impact of the sum of
about 300 cells contributions on the final distribution. In particular, the peak of the
total distribution is less sharp; the Max being computed once the other parameters have
been retrieved, it is difficult, on such a summed up, flattened distribution, to assess this
maximum with the same precision as for a single cell. For these reasons, sticking to a
single cell seems better.

The solution chosen, which still has drawbacks, is to keep only the cells having the
most statistics, namely, those from the first two superlayers (for a total of 4 layers). In
addition to that, at least 400 hits/cell are requested, along with a greater than 6 ADC
hits to ensure the rightness of the fit (some avatar appears on the distributions between
5 and 6 ADC hits, which are suppressed by this selection). Finally, as can be seen in
Figure 5.26, the χ2/ndof of the distribution fits are mainly kept around the unity; the
only events kept are those for which χ2/ndf < 3, which eliminates only one over more
than 30 000 events. 20 % of the statistics (one every 5 run) was used.

5.5.3. Temperature correlations

As presented earlier, there are two types of temperature sensors: 6 per side (4 at the
corners and 2 at the center), and, for each of the 6 High Voltage power supplies (also
called EHV, or Bricks), 1 additional sensor. We would like to know if the correlation is
rather related to the Brick sensors or the temperatures of the face of the calorimeter.

After having applied temperature corrections possible aging effects are checked. The first

5.6. Conclusion

The minimum ionizing particles allow to see relative variations, at the level of 0.22 %/ ◦C.
This was important to verify the precision point, the attenuation corrections, and the
temperature effects. No aging effect has been measured so far, after more than 2 years of
data taking in space; on the contrary, there seems to be a small increase of MIP values
over time. The method is accurate and a variation at the level of a few per mil has been
measured. We can monitor accurately a possible future aging of the calorimeter.



6
The ECAL-standalone Charge Estimator (EQE)

Ce chapitre conclut l’étude des performances du calorimètre électromagnétique

par la construction d’un estimateur de charge nucléaire utilisant uniquement

ce sous-détecteur. Une étude est menée afin de déterminer la pertinence

d’aller en-deçà de l’unité simple de la cellule, utilisée jusqu’ici, pour descendre

au niveau des fibres. Une modélisation tridimensionnelle du calorimètre

est réalisée, et ses résultats analysés sur des simulations et des données

faisceaux. Un estimateur est enfin construit grâce à une méthode de maximum

de vraisemblance utilisant l’énergie déposée dans les couches au MIP. Ses

performances, en fonction du nombre de couches touchées et de la charge des

particules incidentes, sont précisées. Des corrections pour les charges au-delà

de l’oxygène sont enfin appliquées.

—

6.1. Going beyond the cell level

6.1.1. Cell position correction

Until now, the best level of precision reached when computing MIP, for example, was
the cell. While it is sufficient for the purposes exposed, like monitoring the MIP on a
day-to-day basis, for which the main uncertainty sources come from other parameters
(low statistics, accuracy of the fit), our goal is to know whether it is possible, or not,

attenuation and equalization, another correction is applied. The Figure 6.1a recalls the
structure of a single PMT. We can see that four light guides are used to collect the light.
The shape is such that, between the guides, in the middle and on the edges of each
PMT, the light can not be collected. It reflects in the signal collected, as can be seen in
Figure 6.1b, taken during the scan of fibers in the BT 2007 campaign, which shows S1,

which is not the case (two adjacent fibers of the same layer in the lead are closer than

6.1.4. Drawbacks of the 2D model

The previous two-dimensional model suffers several drawbacks.

The unit of the result is unpractical Of course, it could easily be transposed from

A single layer was taken into account A complete model, using both unequally spaced

6.2. Results for the 3D model 141

The model is only two-dimensional This is a major drawback; indeed, on a three-
dimensional representation, by considering a punctual particle defined by its entry and
exit points separated by the three distances in Cartesian coordinates ∆x, ∆y and ∆z,
the path length PL is given by:

PL =
√

(∆x)2 + (∆y)2 + (∆z)2 (6.1.1)

This implies that:

• the overall path length was underestimated by not taking into account the component
along the dimension of the fiber.

• the equation equation (6.1.1) is clearly not linear in ∆y, so the previous result can
not be weighted with a “mean path length” in the third direction, the one from the
fiber.

Therefore, a full three-dimensional model has to be realized.

6.2. Results for the 3D model

6.2.1. The model

Fibers The brick used for the model is a purely geometrical fiber shaped as a three-
dimensional cylinder, as shown in Figure 6.5. For the implementation, the cosmic rays
crossing one single fiber are assumed to be mono-dimensional (along a line), and are
parameterized with a point and a director vector. We determine if the ray crosses the
fiber, in which case the two impact points, t1 and t2 are computed, which allows to
retrieve the positions of those entry and exit points. We then get the path length inside
the fiber using equation (6.1.1), or 0 if the ray does not cross the fiber.

Layer A layer made of fibers is then modeled using the dimensions given in Figure 6.2b.
For the effective implementation, rather than summing the total path length in the layer
on all fibers (a first implementation which proved to be really time-consuming), among
each of the five fibers “sub-layers”, only the one or two fibers closest to the crossing
cosmic ray are determined and taken into account. The effective path length for a layer is

6.2.2. C++ implementation

The model was finally embedded into a C++ class, which had two constructors.

• One of them, used for effective Monte-Carlo computing, was initialized with six
parameters, the three coordinates of one arbitrary point of the trajectory of the
cosmic-ray in the AMS referential, and the three of a pointing vector.

• The other one was initialized with a ParticleR particle of the official AMS software
(either MC, BT or ISS data), and took advantage of the ability given by the tracker
methods of the software to extrapolate the track of the particle on top and bottom
of the calorimeter, providing the point and vector needed to define the trajectory of
the particle.

The user has several public methods to get, as a floating point, the information
desired:

• FiberLayerLength(int l) gives the path length in the fibers of layer l, as described.

• TotLayerLength(int l) gives the total length of matter (fiber and lead) crossed
by the particle in layer l using the cuboid made of a layer and using a formula
similar to equation (6.1.1).

• LeadLayerLength(int l) returns the difference between the total and fiber path
length for layer l. Note that it is not exactly the length of lead crossed since there
exists a shell of glu between fibers and lead, which is not subtracted from the result.

• FracLayerLength(int l) returns the ratio between fiber and lead path lengths for
layer l.

• FiberTotalLength, TotTotalLength, LeadTotalLength and FracTotalLength

give the sum of the previous respective methods over all layers.

6.2.4. Interlude: the Bertrand paradox and the notion of mean

path length

Our goal is to estimate the mean path length of cosmic rays inside the calorimeter, but it
rises difficulties similar to that encountered in the complex determination of the detector



146 Chapter 6. The ECAL-standalone Charge Estimator (EQE)

acceptance. The sort of problem arising when scanning our fibers can be understood
through the analogy of a problem posed in 1889 by Bertrand [Ber89] and since then
known as the Bertrand Paradox, which applies here. Going back to our two-dimensional
model, the goal is to estimate, when scanning the fibers with a Monte-Carlo, which
fraction of path lengths is greater than the length L = 31/2 of an edge of a triangle whose
circumscribed circle is our fiber section, as shown in Figure 6.8.

•

(a) Angular scan from a given
point

(b) Linear scan from a given height

Figure 6.8.: the Bertrand Paradox

We consider two methods:

1. Figure 6.8a: as was done before, one point, say the top of the fiber is fixed, and a
scan by angles of regular step is made. The red lines have a path length greater than
L, and the green, dashed ones, smaller. It appears that, under those assumptions,
the probability of the path length to be greater than L is one third.

2. Figure 6.8b: cosmic rays incoming with an arbitrary, but fixed, angle on top on
the calorimeter are considered, and the fiber is scanned along the top of it. To
help visualize, a radius of the circle and the perpendicular diameter were drawn
in orange, and only half of the rays, whose color is the same as before. This time,
the probability of the path length to be greater (red lines) than L is one half, in
contradiction with the previous case.

In fact, the probability depends solely on our definition of what “random” is, and,
depending on it, a probablity of either one third, one half, one quarter, and still other
values can be found. Therefore, in order to properly estimate the mean path length
crossed, rely on Monte-Carlo only is not sufficient and actual data have to be used.

6.2.6. From geometrical to physical model

From the low dispersion of the fibers/matter ratio, and taking into account the increasing
computing time induced, arises the question of the relevance to compute, or not, the
path length for each event. Two other arguments against it are pushed forward.

First, as was explained in Section 4.5, the Tracker planes move. This effect is taken
into account by the TAS, but the variations of the position are not computed “on-the-fly”,
which, for once, requires to wait before having the relevant calibration, and secondly,
induces great uncertainties on the position of the particle with respect to that of the
fibers belonging to the last planes. A piece of code was made by W. Xu, who sent it to
us, but its implementation in our code did not give any better precision on the spread
observed in data.

Secondly, our purely geometrical description doesn’t match the reality of the calorime-
ter. This is clearly seen in Figure 6.10, where between two odd (or even) rows, the
position of the fibers do not match. It introduces an averaging of the path length over
the course of the full calorimeter which, once again, discourages to implement the precise
event-by-event path length reconstruction. On this subject, some efforts, in collaboration
with W. Xu, were made to go beyond the cell level. It is true that, when scanning
with purely vertical particles, and by taking into account all energy corrections, some
path lengths effects impacting the reconstructed energy are seen, in particular in the

As was said in commentary, having a simultaneous measurement of the energy loss and of
the momentum, as it is effectively done with AMS-02, provides a sensitive measurement
of the charge of the incident particle.

One could wonder why, when both Tracker, TOF and RICH already provide an
accurate charge measurement, it is useful to add another determination from a subdetector
whose primary purposes are totally different.

Three main reasons can be seen:

• First, it provides a useful independent cross-check of the other measurements. In
that matter, the goal is not only to find a result similar to the one of the other
subdetectors. Indeed, along their way in the detector, some heavier nuclei will
interact with the various elements of the detector, which can lead them to split
into several fragments (a phenomenon known as fragmentation). If, for example,
the Upper TOF and Tracker measure a charge q1, and the Lower TOF q2 < q1,
the ECAL could give an information whether there was effective fragmentation or
Lower TOF measured a wrong charge.



150 Chapter 6. The ECAL-standalone Charge Estimator (EQE)

• Then, if the fragmentation rate between the different subdetectors is accurately
estimated, it will give hints about the interaction length inside the detector. This
interaction length is a powerful estimator of the total matter crossed by particles,
in particular additional matter not taken into account, for example in front of the
detector itself (interactions with the ISS, for instance). Knowing these fragmentation
rates and interaction length are primordial to estimate, for example, the B/C ratio,
which is one of the main results expected from AMS. Therefore it is important to
estimate the charge along the detector, including into the ECAL.

• Finally, in the scope of Data Quality assessment, higher-charge nuclei are much
less frequent than protons MIPs, but have a MIP value greater than them; 10 % of
MIPs are helium, which gives us enough statistics to calibrate on a day-to-day basis
with two points measured (getting rid of pedestal effects), and the higher nuclei
(such as carbon or oxygen) allow us to check for non-linearity effects of the energy
measurement up to a few GeV.

A preliminary study consists in checking the possibility to identify the different nuclei
in the calorimeter. We want to see if peaks above the protons and helium ones (clearly

6.5.1. Maximum Likelihood Estimators

The problem is the following: given a particular MIP event of unknown charge q, but of
known dE/dX for each layer, and knowing the distributions of the charge for various
MIP events, the goal is to estimate the charge q of our event, or, in other words, find the
value of the charge which, given the distribution of n variables dE/dX corresponding to
the event, would have the best likelihood to describe them (a multivariate observation
of n variables being the same as a sample of n independent observations because these

6.6. Performances of the estimator

6.6.1. Influence of the number of layers

The MLE is based on the multivariate observation of n variables (one for each layer at
MIP), seen as a sample of n independent observations. It is expected that, the more
layers are hit, the more precise the estimator will be. The event selection is divided into
18 subsamples, each of them corresponding to a different number of layers hit before the
apex, from 0 to 17. For example, the fifth sample contains all the events where at least
five layers were hit. Since it also contains the events where 6, 7, or more layers where hit,
the larger is the number of layers hit, the less statistics it contains.

Figure 6.16 shows the raw distribution of the estimator obtained when 5, 10, 15, and
all layers are fired. It is noticeable that, as expected from the linearity (and subsequent
calibration) of our estimator, the peaks are centered around the integer values. It allowed
to implement an automatic fitting procedure: for each of our 18 subsamples, each of the
8 nuclei peaks, n, was fitted with a normal distribution, by restricting the fitting range
to [n − 0.4, n + 0.4]. Two parameters per fit were kept, the mean of the fit and its RMS,
for a total of 18 × 8 × 2 = 288 parameters.

Figure 6.17 shows the results for the four peaks having the most statistics: H, He,
B and C. For the four species, the right mean charge value is obtained by requesting
at least 9 layers hit, the Helium charge being correctly estimated even with a single
layer at MIP. Note that, if the mean value is quickly obtained, the dispersion is more
dependent on the number of layers, as can be seen in Figure 6.17b. Furthermore, by the
construction of the estimator, the RMS is divided by the nuclei number, which explains
that the protons, although having by far the greatest statistics, have a rather poor score
on their RMS determination. In that matter, the Helium nuclei are the best ranked,
having good statistics and benefiting from a dividing factor of 2. The interesting fact
is that, when at least 13 layers are hit, a dispersion smaller than 10 % is obtained. For
helium and carbon the dispersion is even in the order of 7 %.

Proton/electron rejection: a first estimator

Les parties précédentes ont permis de décrire les objectifs du détecteur AMS-02,

ainsi que ses performances. Nous pouvons désormais passer à l’étude propre-

ment dite de la discrimination électrons-protons. Ce chapitre, tout d’abord,

revient sur les motivations d’une telle discrimination et définit quelques con-

à la réalisation pratique d’une analyse multivariée (jeux de données, type de

variables mises en jeu). Un premier estimateur, utilisant les premiers mois

de données sur la station, ainsi que les événements issus des tests faisceaux,

est alors mis en oeuvre. Ses limites, en termes de pouvoir discriminant aux

plus hautes énergies, sont montrées, impliquant la nécessité de construire un

—

7.1. Motivations

As seen in the previous Chapters, the AMS-02 experiment, due to the sustained quality
of the instrument during time, offers an excellent probe to determine the precise spectra
of all cosmic-ray species. Among the ones of particular interest, Section 2.3.3 shows how
the protons/antiproton, and electron/positron pairs resulting from an eventual WIMP
annihilation could be of particular interest. However, as was shown in Chapter 3, the
primary fluxes of cosmic rays are mainly made of protons, followed by helium nuclei, and

169



170 Chapter 7. Proton/electron rejection: a first estimator

electrons. The fluxes of these particles come for their greater part from other astrophysical
phenomena, and, therefore, an antimatter signal in those channels would be drown by
them. The indirect study of Dark Matter through its products in the standard model
can mainly be carried into the antimatter channels, expected to consist for its greater
part of secondary particles, namely positrons and antiprotons.

The distinction between a particle and its antiparticle, given by the sign of the charge,
can only be retrieved through the Tracker, while the discrimination between hadronic and
leptonic species is done through two subdetectors: the TRD, more efficient, by design, at
the lower energies (up to 100 GeV), and the ECAL, whose best results will be obtained at
the highest energies. In what follows, the focus is made on the results of the ECAL only.

For what concerns the antiparticles of interest, at a given energy, there are about
ten times less antiprotons than positrons in the spectra; towards the goal of having the
greatest possible statistics, this study focuses on leptonic species. In what follows, the
background is defined as the hadronic species (protons, antiprotons and helium when
necessary), which have to be gotten rid of, and signal the leptonic species (electrons and
positrons).
